newsitem.title: USA: Big consumer names still shy of online advertising.
newsitem.headline: Big consumer names still shy of online advertising.

text.p: The big consumer brand companies are still relatively shy of advertising in cyberspace and the biggest online advertisers continue to be technology companies, executives said at a conference.

"Consumer brands are still in the wings," said Peter Storck, group director, online advertising, at Jupiter Communications, a market research firm based in New York. "We are still talking to ourselves."
Storck told a Jupiter conference that while some consumer giants are warming up to advertising on the Internet, they make up a small percentage of total advertising sold.

He said that of total Internet advertising in the third quarter this year, computer and Internet-related companies spent 54 percent of the $66 million advertising dollars, which is down slightly from 60 percent in the second quarter.
The top 10 advertisers in the third quarter were all technology companies, led by Netscape Communications Corp, then four Internet search engines, Yahoo!, Infoseek Corp and Excite Inc.
"What are the big brands waiting for?" Storck asked, then explained that the big consumer brand name companies are waiting for more standardized measurement and auditing data.
Storck also said advertisers also want more research that allows them to compare the effectiveness of the online medium, and consistent ad rates.

"Is this medium any more accountable?" said Judy Black, a senior partner at Bozell Inc, the big advertising agency. "There still is an issue of measurement. Many companies still have different ways of measuring."
Storck pointed out that in the recent quarter, automotive companies made up five percent of Internet advertising and other various consumer companies were 15 percent of online ads.
Jupiter expects total online advertising spending to exceed $300 million this year and reach $5 billion in 2000.
